citations.narrative:
During a guided group tour, the facility failed to protect two lemurs from unwanted public contact. The first incident
occurred when a child ignored the instructions of facility personnel and reached through a cage housing a mother and
infant lemur. The child grabbed the young lemur, which was then grasped by the mother resulting in a slight puncture to
the infant lemur's arm. Facility employees were able to intervene and prevent any further contact at this station. A short
time later as the group was exiting the lemur area, the same child left the group and ran back inside the public barrier
where an employee was holding a one-year-old lemur named "Sunday". The child grabbed "Sunday" on the back and was
subsequently bitten or scratched on a finger. Park officials described the injury as a minor scratch with no bleeding and
stated that it was just a reaction by the lemur and not an act of aggression. They also stated that the child continued the
tour and was taken to Urgent Care later that evening. "Sunday" the lemur did not sustain any injuries from this encounter
and is currently in quarantine with a local veterinarian. The infant lemur is recovering from his injury with no complications
at this time.
During public exhibition, all animals must be handled to minimize risk to the animal and to the public. Failure to provide
proper handling poses a risk of injury to animals and members of the public alike. In this case, the result was a minor
injury to both a regulated animal and a member of the public. The facility must take any necessary steps to ensure the
protection of the public and animals.
Correct by 12 May 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
